conclusion: Determine the angle of deviation of the incident light relative to point D.
Triangle ABC is a right triangle with angle A = 90° and angle B = 60°.
Point D is the midpoint of CG.
Point E is on AC where the light reflects.
Point F is on AB where total internal reflection occurs.
Point G is the intersection of EG with BC, where EG is perpendicular to AC.
Angle C is 30° because angle A is 90° and angle B is 60°.
EG is perpendicular to AC, so angle CEG is 90°.
The angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection at E.
Total internal reflection occurs when the angle of incidence is greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle is given by sin θc = 1/n, where n is the refractive index.
Focus on geometry since n is not given.
The deviation angle is the angle between the initial and final direction of the light.
The deviation angle δ can be found by considering angles at E and F.
Since angle B is 60°, and the light reflects symmetrically, calculate deviation based on reflection angles.
The deviation angle δ is twice the angle of incidence at E due to symmetry.
The angle of deviation of the incident light relative to point D is 120°.
